message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The thickening of glomerular basement membrane and subepithelial deposits suggest Membranous Nephropathy as the most likely diagnosis. Postinfectious glomerulonephritis is associated with recent infection, Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis shows segmental scars, and Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis is associated with crescent formation.

We refer to a medical article for help. The presence of proteinuria and subepithelial spike and dome deposits seen on electron microscopy are characteristic of membranous nephropathy. The thickening of the glomerular basement membrane is also commonly seen in membranous nephropathy. The other options typically have different microscopic findings, such as crescents in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and focal or segmental glomerulosclerosis in FSGS. Postinfectious glomerulonephritis also typically presents with a recent infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The thickening of the glomerular basement membrane and subepithelial spike and dome deposits present in electron microscopy suggest the most likely diagnosis to be membranous nephropathy. Postinfectious glomerulonephritis presents with a history of recent infection, while Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis presents with foot process fusion seen in electron microscopy. Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis is characterized by acute renal failure and crescents on biopsy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane and subepithelial spike and dome deposits suggest the most likely diagnosis is membranous nephropathy. None of the other options show these findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of pitting edema and proteinuria, along with the glomerular basement membrane thickening and subepithelial deposits seen on biopsy, suggest the diagnosis of membranous nephropathy. Postinfectious glomerulonephritis would have a history of recent infection, while Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis and Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis would have different biopsy findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The thickening of the glomerular basement membrane and presence of subepithelial spike and dome deposits seen on electron microscopy are characteristic findings of membranous nephropathy, making it the most likely diagnosis. Postinfectious glomerulonephritis and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis are typically associated with crescent formation, while focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is characterized by segmental glomerular sclerosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane and subepithelial spike and dome deposits are classic findings of membranous nephropathy. Postinfectious glomerulonephritis usually presents with hematuria and proteinuria after a recent infection. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis presents with proteinuria and a focal and segmental pattern of glomerular damage. Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis presents with rapidly worsening kidney function and often has a crescentic pattern of glomerular injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The thickening of the GBM and the subepithelial deposits are classic findings for membranous nephropathy. Postinfectious glomerulonephritis and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis usually show signs of inflammation. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis presents with segmental sclerosis and hyalinosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of 2+ pitting edema in legs and the finding of proteinuria indicates a kidney problem. The biopsy results suggest Membranous Nephropathy, which is characterized by diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane and subepithelial spike and dome deposits. None of the other options have these specific biopsy findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The thickening of the glomerular basement membrane and subepithelial deposits are characteristic of membranous nephropathy. Postinfectious glomerulonephritis would show immune complex deposits, while FSGS and RPGN would show different types of glomerular damage. The proteinuria supports the diagnosis of membranous nephropathy.
